title.narrative: Response to unattended health needs in vulnerable municipalities of multiple affectations in Honduras.

description.narrative: The main objective of this project is to ensure the continuity and availability of health services to prevent disproportionate mortality and morbidity. This WHO project provides 1) basic repairs to damaged and unsanitary health facilities, 2) essential health supplies, equipment, PPEs, maternal and reproductive health supplies to health centers, and 3) community-based or health-facility-based disease surveillance among other activities. The project provides humanitarian assistance to 100,000 people, including 26,400 men, 28,600 women, 45,000 children, and including 1,000 persons with disabilities.

owner-org.narrative: UN OCHA Central Emergency Response Fund (CERF)

organisation.narrative: UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA)

mailing-address.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA), Central Emergency Response Fund (CERF), 2 United Nations Plaza (DC2), East 44th street (13th floor), United Nations, New York, USA

description.narrative: Disbursement to CERF Project Response to unattended health needs in vulnerable municipalities of multiple affectations in Honduras.

title.narrative: RESIDENT / HUMANITARIAN COORDINATOR REPORT ON THE USE OF CERF FUNDS HONDURAS UNDERFUNDED EMERGENCIES ECONOMIC DISRUPTION 2022

condition.narrative: CERF funding is based on an agreed proposal, including specific planned outcomes and outputs.

description.narrative: 100,000 members of vulnerable communities are better protected from risks of disease outbreaks through improved timely detection and control of infectious hazards and increased risk communication around communicable health threats.

CC.1 Number of implementing partner staff receiving training to support programme implementation (frontline aid workers trained on epi surveillance, outbreak detection and control and infectious hazards management.)
H.5 Percentage of public health alerts generated through community-based or health-facility-based surveillance or alert systems investigated within 24 hours.Target: At least 50%.
Number of community members sensitized around risks of disease outbreak and protective measures.
Number of health establishments or health regions in the affected areas where epidemiological surveillance has been reestablished.
Number of health regions in the affected areas where epidemiological surveillance has been reestablished.
50,000 women, men and children have continued access to safe, quality, gender-sensitive and culturally appropriate essential health services.
H.7 Number of functional health facilities supported (health facilities with restored capacity to pre-disaster level.)
H.7 Number of functional health facilities supported (with basic equipment for emergency care; maternal, obstetric, neonatal, and paediatric care and PPEs)
H.8 Number of primary healthcare consultations provided.Target: At least 2,000 primary healthcare consultations provided.
Number of medical brigades successfully delivering life-saving healthcare services to affected communities.
Mental health assistance streamlined and scaled-up to protect frontline workers and vulnerable population in municipalities faced with multi-affectation.
CC.1 implementing partner staff receiving training to support programme implementation ( (psychosocial and mental health assistance and self-care strategies.)
Number of community members who receive information on mental health and psychosocial support.
